channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russia-Ukraine War: Russian Reports of Drone Attacks Aimed at Moscow Tick Up
item.description: Russia said it had shot down two drones near the capital on Wednesday. Its Ministry of Defense has reported that 12 drones were aimed at Moscow in recent weeks.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times

item.title: After Russian Attack in Ukraine, Broken Glass and Rattled Nerves in Romania
item.description: A drone assault on a Danube River port sent shock waves — both the physical and the psychological kind — into villages just across the water that are in NATO territory.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Andreea Campeanu for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gheorghe Puflea, 71, said he was woken by the sounds of explosions and shattering glass when Russia attacked a port across the river from his shack in Plauru, Romania.

item.title: Can Frozen Peas, Long Taken for Granted, Find New Appeal in the U.K.?
item.description: Britain’s vegetable producers are hoping this is a moment for the humble frozen pea, a cost-effective staple at a time of rising food prices.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Using a pea viner — a 25-ton harvester that moves at less than 1 mile per hour — in Boston, England, in July.

item.title: Amid Niger Coup, Nigeria Grapples with Potential Military Intervention
item.description: An ongoing coup in Niger could shape the future of a West African regional bloc and the presidency of Bola Ahmed Tinubu, the newly elected leader of Nigeria.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Ismail Alfa
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas)
item.media:description: President Bola Ahmed Tinubu of Nigeria, center, at a gathering of the African Union in Nairobi, Kenya, last month.

item.title: Imran Khan Appeals Prison Sentence in Pakistan
item.description: The former prime minister of Pakistan was jailed after being found guilty in a corruption case. The legal fight will determine his political future ahead of elections later this year.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:description: Legal representatives for former Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan at the High Court in the capital, Islamabad, on Wednesday. Mr. Khan was arrested and jailed on Sunday.

item.title: 11 Killed in Vacation Home Fire in France
item.description: The victims were on an organized trip for people with mental disabilities in Wintzenheim, near the borders of Germany and Switzerland.
item.dc:creator: Juliette Guéron-Gabrielle and Claire Moses
item.media:description: Twenty-eight vacationers were staying at the holiday home in Wintzenheim, France, when it caught fire early Wednesday morning.

item.title: Dozens of Migrants Die After Boat Sinks in Strait of Sicily
item.description: Survivors said that 41 people, shunted by traffickers onto a small makeshift iron vessel, had drowned after it capsized en route from Tunisia to Italy.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A pile of boats of the type often used by migrants in Sfax, Tunisia. Traffickers have increasingly crowded people onto such makeshift, poorly constructed vessels for the perilous sea crossing to Europe.

item.title: Was That an Earthquake in Rome? No, It Was a Travis Scott Concert.
item.description: The rap star’s show in Rome at the Circus Maximus, an archaeological site by day and concert venue by night, has raised concerns about the risks posed by crowds.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Francesco Lastrucci for The New York Times
item.media:description: A view of the Circus Maximus and Palatine Hill in Rome last year.

item.title: U.S. Nurse and Her Child Released by Kidnappers in Haiti
item.description: The abduction came as gang violence has begun cresting in Haiti and an international force may be headed to the Caribbean island nation to address the insecurity.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: Alix Dorsainvil, who was freed after her abduction. She is seen here with her husband, Sandro, who directs the aid group she worked with.

item.title: Mushroom Poisoning Suspected in 3 Deaths, Australia Police Say
item.description: The three guests, and a fourth who fell ill, had symptoms consistent with mushroom poisoning, the police say. The woman who served the meal has been questioned by the police.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Poisoning from death cap mushrooms, like the ones on the left, is suspected to have caused the deaths of three guests at a lunch last month in the Australian state of Victoria.

item.title: Trudeau Searches For a New Image After Separation From His Wife
item.description: Justin Trudeau has portrayed himself as a modern husband, father and political figure in his rise to prime minister. How does he redefine himself after the breakup of his 18-year marriage?
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:description: Justin Trudeau and his wife, Sophie Grégoire Trudeau, in his father’s 1959 Mercedes roadster after their wedding ceremony in Montreal in 2005.

item.title: 98 Arrests in Child Abuse Inquiry That Followed Killing of F.B.I. Agents
item.description: The investigation the two agents were part of grew into a larger inquiry that netted members of an online pedophile ring in the U.S. and Australia.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Law enforcement officers near an apartment complex where two F.B.I. agents were killed during a child abuse investigation in Sunrise, Fla., in 2021.

item.title: Weather Punishes Europe, With Portugal Wildfires and Slovenia Floods
item.description: The extreme weather across the continent this summer has destroyed huge amounts of land, forced many to evacuate, and in some cases caused deaths.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Dropping water over a fire in Apesia, southern Cyprus, on Monday.

item.title: The Taliban Won but These Afghans Fought On
item.description: But the Afghan resistance movement is no match for the Taliban’s military might.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Najim Rahim

item.title: Rodriguez, Singer Whose Career Was Resurrected, Dies at 81
item.description: Two albums in the early 1970s went largely unnoticed in the United States, but not overseas. Then came the 2012 documentary “Searching for Sugar Man.”
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger
item.media:description: The singer Rodriguez in 2012, the year he was the subject of the documentary “Searching for Sugar Man.”

item.title: Russia Downs 2 Drones Near Moscow, as Ukraine War’s New Phase Intensifies
item.description: It was the 12th time in the past three weeks that Russian officials had reported intercepting such aerial attacks in the heart of the capital.
item.dc:creator: Enjoli Liston, Valeriya Safronova and Paul Sonne
item.media:description: Military and police officials at the entrance of the Zagorsk Optical and Mechanical Plant, less than 50 miles from Moscow, after an explosion on Wednesday.

item.title: Russian Missile Hits Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine, Killing 2
item.description: Officials said seven people were injured, a church building and several local shops were destroyed, and the windows were blown out of several high-rise buildings.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The city of Zaporizhzhia was struck by a Russian missile on Wednesday evening, Ukrainian officials said.

item.title: Biden Orders Ban on New Investments in China’s Sensitive High-Tech Industries
item.description: The new limits, aimed at preventing American help to Beijing as it modernizes its military, escalate a conflict between the world’s two largest economies.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: An order by President Biden will prohibit venture capital and private equity firms from pumping money into Chinese efforts to develop semiconductors and other microelectronics.

item.title: Does Information Affect Our Beliefs?
item.description: New studies on social media’s influence tell a complicated story.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Four recent academic papers found that algorithms used by Facebook wielded considerable influence over the spread of information but that did not significantly effect people’s underlying beliefs.

item.title: Poland to Deploy 2,000 Troops To Reinforce Belarus Border
item.description: The deployment comes as concerns are mounting in Poland, a NATO member, over the presence of mercenaries from Russia’s Wagner private military company in neighboring Belarus.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: A Polish guard patrolling along a fence at the Belarusian border in May. Poland, a NATO member, is adding 2,000 more military troops to the border.

item.title: At Least 60 Injured in Factory Explosion at Plant In Moscow
item.description: Russian officials said one person was killed and dozens were injured in the blast. The warehouse is on the grounds of a plant that has produced night vision devices and binoculars, according to local news media.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Valeriya Safronova
item.media:description: Law enforcement officers standing guard at the entrance to the Zagorsk Optical-Mechanical Plant in Sergiev Posad, Russia on Wednesday, after a large explosion in the area.

item.title: Baseball Players Visit Mexico’s Basilica de Santa María de Guadalupe
item.description: When in the capital for road games, many Mexican League players join the throngs paying their respects at the Basílica de Santa María de Guadalupe.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner and Alejandro Cegarra
item.media:description: Isidro Piña, a professional baseball player for the Olmecas de Tabasco, organized a trip with his teammates Mario Morales and Daniel Nuñez to the Basílica de Santa María de Guadalupe.

item.title: How 4 Countries Are Preparing to Bring Stolen Treasures Home
item.description: While attention is focused on western museums and governments giving back looted items, heritage workers in the global south are laying the groundwork for new claims.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Hickley

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: A troubled Black Sea.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Russian marines during Navy Day celebrations in Russia’s Black Sea port of Novorossiysk last month. The Black Sea is suddenly a cauldron of military and geopolitical tensions.

item.title: Biden to Restrict Investments in China, Citing National Security Threats
item.description: The measure to clamp down on investments in certain industries deemed to pose security risks, set to be issued Wednesday, appears likely to open a new front in the U.S.-China economic conflict.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: The restrictions issued by President Biden will bar private equity and venture capital firms from making investments in certain high-tech sectors.

item.title: Russian Missile Strikes in Pokrovsk, Ukraine, Kill 9 and Wound Dozens More
item.description: Ukrainians say the explosions 37 minutes apart in Pokrovsk, which killed at least nine people and injured 82 others, were a “double tap” intended to kill rescuers responding to the first strike.
item.dc:creator: Gaëlle Girbes and Marc Santora
item.media:description: The aftermath Tuesday morning of Russian shelling in Pokrovsk, a small city in eastern Ukraine, twice in quick succession on Monday, that killed at least nine people.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Few Jobs for Chinese Graduates
item.description: Also, Afghans try to resist the Taliban and Niger’s coup leaders shun diplomats.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Chinese students after the first day of the national college entrance exams.

item.title: TSMC Will Build a Semiconductor Plant in Germany
item.description: TSMC, the world’s largest maker of semiconductors, said it would invest $3.8 billion in a joint project with three European industrial firms.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy and John Liu
item.media:description: TSMC announced a joint project to build a production facility for microchips in eastern Germany; the plant would be its first in Europe.

item.title: UK Expands Sanctions List to Target Russia’s Weapons Suppliers
item.description: New measures announced Tuesday will affect businesses in Turkey, Dubai and Iran, as well as individuals that Britain says have supplied weaponry or components needed to sustain Russia’s war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Damage in Pokrovsk, Ukraine, on Tuesday, after a Russian attack.

item.title: Hopes for Dialogue Dim in Niger as Junta Clings to Power
item.description: A leader of the coup in Niger who had been considered a close U.S. ally rejected a request from a visiting U.S. diplomat to release the country’s democratically elected president and bring back constitutional order.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Eric Schmitt
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas)
item.media:description: Members of a military council that staged a coup in Niger attending a rally at a stadium in the capital, Niamey, on Sunday.

item.title: British Museum Stabbing: Man Wounded
item.description: The stabbing outside the popular tourist attraction was not related to terrorism, the police said. A suspect has been arrested.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Jordan Pettitt/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A crowd gathers at the entrance to the British Museum on Tuesday after a man was stabbed outside the building.

item.title: Turbulent Waters: How the Black Sea Became a Hot Spot in the War
item.description: The Black Sea, a largely overlooked part of the war in Ukraine, is suddenly a cauldron of military and geopolitical tensions. The region is deeply important to Moscow, Ukraine and the West.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Russian marines during Navy Day celebrations in Russia’s Black Sea port of Novorossiysk last month. The Black Sea is suddenly a cauldron of military and geopolitical tensions.

item.title: UAE, a US Ally, Looks to China and Russia for Deeper Ties
item.description: The United Arab Emirates, which has translated its wealth into outsize global influence, is diverging from U.S. foreign policy — particularly when it comes to isolating Russia and limiting ties with China.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:credit: Andrea DiCenzo for The New York Times
item.media:description: The marina district in Dubai. The Emirates has thrived on an influx of Russian money, oil and gold, fueling a feeding frenzy in real estate.

item.title: Ireland Says Goodbye to Sinéad O’Connor at Funeral Procession
item.description: In the coastal town of Bray, south of Dublin, the site of Ms. O’Connor’s last Irish home, mourners gathered to pay their respects to the singer.
item.dc:creator: Ed O’Loughlin
item.media:description: A hearse carrying the coffin of Sinead O’Connor passed outside her former home in Bray, Ireland, on Tuesday.

item.title: South Korea Braces for Typhoon Khanun as It Barrels Over Japan
item.description: The storm, which battered Okinawa last week, engulfed the southern Japanese island of Kyushu on its way toward the Korean Peninsula.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Fishing boats were anchored in a port on Jeju Island, South Korea, on Wednesday, before the expected arrival of Typhoon Khanun.

item.title: As Weather Threats Loom, Even Chimps Learn to Shelter in Place
item.description: How do you teach 300 chimpanzees to seek safety in a storm? With cowbells, sound machines and a bright orange Frisbee.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes and Emil T. Lippe
item.media:credit: Emil T. Lippe for The New York Times

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Upheaval in the Chinese military.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, China’s leader.

item.title: Video Shows China Blasting Water Cannon at Philippines Coast Guard Boat
item.description: The clash, in which a Chinese ship blocked 2 Philippine vessels, is the latest in a hotly contested region of the South China Sea.
item.media:credit: Philippine Coast Guard, via Associated Press

item.title: Ukraine Says Russian Missiles Struck Town of Pokrovsk, Killing 5
item.description: The strikes hit the center of the small city in eastern Ukraine twice within 40 minutes, officials said. At least 31 people were injured.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: Rescue workers at a residential building destroyed by a Russian missile strike in Pokrovsk, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Elite Chinese Generals Ousted
item.description: Also, South Korea relocates an international scout convention as a typhoon looms.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, has taken pride in turning the 98 million-strong Communist Party and the Chinese military into unquestioning enforcers of his rule.

item.title: Foreign Ministers of China and Russia Confer Phone After Jeddah Talks
item.description: China underscored its desire to “actively promote” efforts to end the war in Ukraine “on any multilateral occasion.”
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov of Russia with China’s top diplomat, Wang Yi, last month on the sidelines of Southeast Asian talks in Jakarta, Indonesia, in a photo released by the Russian Foreign Ministry.

item.title: Gaza Protests Struggle to Gain Traction as Police Crack Down
item.description: Demonstrators’ efforts to rally against Hamas, including at protests on Monday, have been foiled by a heavy security presence.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Iyad Abuheweila
item.media:description: A Palestinian girl in the Gaza Strip tries to stay cool during a heat wave last week when power outages compounded frustrations with Hamas.

item.title: UK Moves First Group of Migrants to Barge
item.description: A small group of migrants was transferred to the Bibby Stockholm, a divisive symbol of the Conservative government’s immigration stance.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: The Bibby Stockholm, foreground, a barge that can accommodate 500 people, was moored in Portland, southwest England, on Monday.

item.title: Ukraine Replaces the Soviet Symbol on the Motherland Monument
item.description: The Motherland Monument — a 335-foot-tall stainless steel behemoth towering over Ukraine’s capital — was unveiled in 1981 and designed to assert Soviet invincibility.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Sarah Eckinger

item.title: South Korea Tells Scouts to Quit World Jamboree Site as Typhoon Nears
item.description: The main campsite for the troubled gathering will be packed up and thousands of scouts will disperse across the country until the event ends on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: U.S. scouts preparing to leave the World Scout Jamboree campsite in Buan, South Korea, on Sunday.

item.title: South Korean Cities Play Matchmaker to Singles Wanting to Mingle
item.description: Singles are signing up in droves for city-hosted blind-dating events, but some point to their inability to address real issues with family planning.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon

item.title: Ukraine’s Marines Urge Patience With Counterattack Against Russia
item.description: Journalists from The Times spent two weeks with troops from brigades trained and supplied by NATO to get their take on how, and where, the counteroffensive is going.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall, Oleksandr Chubko and Diego Ibarra Sanchez
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sánchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops near the southern front line.

item.title: Xi Remade China’s Military. Now a Purge Threatens its Image.
item.description: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, set out to clean up the military a decade ago. But now his crown jewel, the missile force, is under a shadow.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, has taken pride in turning the 98 million-strong Communist Party and the Chinese military into unquestioning enforcers of his rule.

item.title: Israeli Missile Strike Kills 4 Near Damascus, Syria Says
item.description: A report in Syrian state media said the attack had come from the Golan Heights. The four killed were soldiers, it said.
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: Monday Briefing: Khan Arrested in Pakistan
item.description: Also, diverted floodwaters provoke anger in China.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Imran Khan, center, at an office of Lahore High Court in Lahore, Pakistan, last month.

item.title: At Least 24 Killed in Minibus Crash in Morocco
item.description: The vehicle overturned at a curve on its way to a weekly town market southeast of Marrakesh, officials said.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Families and security officials outside a morgue in Demnate, Morocco, on Sunday, after a deadly traffic accident that morning.

item.title: Deadline to Junta in Niger From ECOWAS Leaders Runs Out
item.description: A deadline given by a bloc of other West African nations to the Nigerien military junta to reinstate the ousted president ran out with no sign of a military intervention by neighbors.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Omar Hama Saley
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas)
item.media:description: Protesters on Thursday outside the National Assembly in Niamey, Niger’s capital.

item.title: Pakistan Train Derails, Killing at Least 30
item.description: An express train carrying at least 950 passengers was traveling from Karachi to Havelian when 10 carriages fell off the tracks, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood and Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:description: Rescue crews worked at the site of a train derailment on Sunday near Nawabshah, in southern Pakistan.

item.title: In Egypt, Public Classrooms Are Empty as Private Tutors Get Rich
item.description: In a country hobbled by economic crisis, families often turn to private education centers instead of schools to seek better futures for their children, sometimes even sacrificing food to pay for lessons.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Nariman El-Mofty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Egyptian students crammed into the Excellent-Oxford Tutoring Center in a suburb of Cairo for a five-hour private math lesson.

item.title: Putin’s Forever War
item.description: Vladimir Putin wants to lead Russians into a civilizational conflict with the West far larger than Ukraine. Will they follow him?
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and Nanna Heitmann
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Putin’s Forever War

item.title: ‘Barbie’ Is a Sleeper Hit in China
item.description: The movie has exceeded box office expectations, as China’s female moviegoers celebrate a film that addresses women’s rights head-on.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Siyi Zhao
item.media:description: Despite its limited availability in China, the movie “Barbie” has quickly become widely discussed on Chinese social media, setting off its own mini-mania in some circles.

item.title: Ukraine War Expands Beyond Established Battlefields
item.description: Ukraine has grown bolder, firing drones at Moscow, while Russian forces have turned to regular attacks on the Black Sea, a crucial economic lifeline.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Vivek Shankar and Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damaged buildings in Kharkiv, a city in eastern Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: Swiss Women Sue Government Over Climate Change Protections
item.description: A group of Swiss women over 64 has filed a lawsuit against Switzerland with Europe’s top human rights court, saying the country has violated their rights by failing to curb emissions.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Members of KlimaSeniorinnen, or Senior Women for Climate Protection, in 2020 with Marie Toussaint, third from right, a French environmental activist and member of the European Parliament, in Strasbourg, France.

item.title: Victim of Mass Attack in South Korea Dies
item.description: The victim was one of 14 people hurt in a car-and-stabbing rampage on Thursday in a city near Seoul. She had been hit by the car.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: A police officer cordoning off the scene of the attack in Seongnam, South Korea, on Thursday.
